qas.question: How many parts does the trophy come in?

answers.text: The trophy comes in three parts

qas.question: What is the  parts of the trophy?

answers.text: - the cup itself, plus a lid and a base

qas.question: How many trophy designs have there bee?

answers.text: There have been two designs of trophy in use

qas.question: How many physical trophies have been presented?

answers.text: five physical trophies have been presented

qas.question: When was the first design changed?

answers.text: . The FA decided to change the design after the 1909 winners, Manchester United, made their own replica,

qas.question: When was the original trophy created?
What was the new, larger design known as?
How tall was the third replica?
When was the third replica last used?

context: <a0_0>The trophy comes in three parts<a0_0/> <a1_0>- the cup itself, plus a lid and a base<a1_0/>. <a2_0>There have been two designs of trophy in use<a2_0/>, but <a3_0>five physical trophies have been presented<a3_0/>. The original trophy, known as <b6_0>the "little tin idol"<b6_0/>, was <b8_0>18 inches high<b8_0/> and made by Martin, Hall & Co. It was stolen in <b5_0>1895<b5_0/> and never recovered, and so was replaced by an exact replica, used until 1910<a4_0>. The FA decided to change the design after the 1909 winners, Manchester United, made their own replica,<a4_0/> leading the FA to realise they did not own the copyright. This new, larger design was by <b7_0>Messers Fattorini and Sons<b7_0/>, and was used from 1911. In order to preserve this original, from 1992 it was replaced by an exact replica, although this had to be replaced after just over two decades, after showing wear and tear from being handled more than in previous eras. This third replica, first used in <b9_0>2014<b9_0/>, was built heavier to withstand the increased handling. Of the four surviving trophies, only the 1895 replica has entered private ownership.
